1065626706134724610.text: Ok, I gave you the Post version.  So what did the Post leave out?  A bunch.https://www.investors.com/politics/editorials/global-warming-flawed-climate-model/¬†‚Ä¶

1066336168709566464.text: 9/9: Disagree? Provide scientific references - not videos - to support your argument.

1066336600584421377.text: 3/9: ‚Ä¶no evidence that anyone in the climate research community has that. Example: he talks about the Russian climate model. First, there isn‚Äôt just one climate model for Russia, there are several. Here are two examples:

1065834589367689216.text: 5/5: Many other errors and misrepresentations in his talk I could hit on. But this is the heart and soul of his thesis. And he‚Äôs wrong. Therefore the rest of his arguments are, at best, speculative.

1065681172800266240.text: Michaels is on record as, "I do not contest the basic scientific principles behind greenhouse warming and acknowledge that the global mean temperature has increased in recent decades." He doesn't even deny it's from burning fossil fuels. He primarily disagrees on the modeling.

1066336658436444160.text: 2/9: That‚Äôs part of how numerical modeling works (https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/10.1175/BAMS-D-15-00135.1¬†‚Ä¶). If Michaels believes that has been achieved for modeling any aspect of climate, including surface temperature that he talks about in the video, he needs to provide a reference for that since there‚Äôs‚Ä¶

1066336454408695808.text: 5/9: What you‚Äôll find in both is parameterization. Lots and lots of parameterization. Why? Because the models cannot be expressed without it. Second, the Russian model(s) are no better, and in some ways worse, than many of the other peer models. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674927813500219¬†‚Ä¶.

1066336307599667205.text: 7/9: Michaels‚Äô video is a mess. The basis of his criticisms - the models overestimate temperature change because they include the temperature increase up to about 1940, and use of parameterization - are fatally flawed and simply wrong.

1066336528668884994.text: 4/9: First one is from the Institute of Numerical Mathematics of the Russian Academy of Sciences (INM RAS GCCM https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mirseid_Akperov2/publication/227085261_Probability_distributions_for_cyclones_and_anticyclones_from_the_NCEPNCAR_reanalysis_data_and_the_INM_RAS_climate_model/links/55f196f408ae0af8ee1e4b23/Probability-distributions-for-cyclones-and-anticyclones-from-the-NCEP-NCAR-reanalysis-data-and-the-INM-RAS-climate-model.pdf¬†‚Ä¶, the second by several researchers from several institutes in Russia https://www.geosci-model-dev.net/11/665/2018/¬†

1065834314712018945.text: 1/5: I watched it and took notes along the way. Way too much for a twitter conversation. But, the core of Michaels‚Äô argument against models is not enough CO2 produced by burning fossil fuels before 1940 to explain temp increase, and then temp drop, therefore models over estimate.

1065834518911770624.text: 4/5: Coal also drove up aerosols (particulates) dramatically into the atmosphere, which caused a short cooling period. CO2 emissions from the other fossil fuel sources + continued coal use overcame cooling effect.

1065834384249384961.text: 2/5: Models assume increase before was due to CO2 emissions; Michaels says no. Michaels never provides ANY scientific explanation as to why he says CO2 couldn‚Äôt do it. Here are references that explain why he‚Äôs wrong. https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=10¬†‚Ä¶

1065834447407214593.text: 3/5: Note coal use before/after about 1940 and dramatic increase in other fossil fuels after. But found numerous scientific papers that explain during primary coal use lots of CO2 generated and started the greenhouse effect.

1066336735800385536.text: 1/9: @brillianttrave1 A couple of additional thoughts on Michaels‚Äô talk: parameterization and the Russian climate model. With numerical modeling, unless the complete formula for a model is known, parameterization is required.

1066336377556492288.text: 6/9: This critique covers 14 of the 32 models. At least three are equally as good as the INM (Russian) model, and the INM model is much worse than peer models at many aspects of climate

1066336245670768640.text: 8/9: He‚Äôs either terribly uniformed about what he speaks, or he‚Äôs intentionally being deceptive. Given his funding, I suspect the latter, but that‚Äôs just my opinion. If this is the best the climate change deniers can provide, then it‚Äôs a joke.
